issues.title: Streaming for XACT sounds
issues.body:
SoundEffects seem to be more rich in features than MediaPlayer Songs with the exception that **they cannot be streamed**, as such large tracks have to be loaded in memory and also **are not seekable**.

It would be great if there was an option to have a SoundEffect streamable that would also allow us to create instances of it, apply volume, pan, pitch and also seek (get/set) the track position. I understand this would also possibly need a **_AudioStream_** type in the Pipeline tool, which would need the sound converted to the correct audio format per-platform)

[Forum reference topic](http://community.monogame.net/t/audio-features-problem-more-than-1-song-at-a-time-streaming-seeking-sound-effects/10200/4)

issues.title: Seeking track position for MediaPlayer Songs
issues.body:
There should be the ability to be able to **seek MediaPlayer Songs** and get/set their track position while a Song is playing/paused/stopped. 

That would allow cases like skipping parts of a song, syncing the song to the action or creating custom loop points. Following the [reference topic](http://community.monogame.net/t/audio-features-problem-more-than-1-song-at-a-time-streaming-seeking-sound-effects/10200/4), it is stated that seeking works only for a few platforms.

[Forum reference topic](http://community.monogame.net/t/audio-features-problem-more-than-1-song-at-a-time-streaming-seeking-sound-effects/10200/4)

issues.title: Ability for playback of multiple MediaPlayer songs
issues.body:
There should be the ability to **be able to use more than one Song at a time.** 

Common use cases would be to be able to **crossfade between 2 songs** or **use other songs as background ambience** (like sea, birds, rain) and **play together** along with the background music.

[Reference forum topic
](http://community.monogame.net/t/audio-features-problem-more-than-1-song-at-a-time-streaming-seeking-sound-effects/10200)

issues.title: Custom name for Content project in msbuild pipeline is not configurable
issues.body:
In XNA it is possible to rename a content project. This would place the resulting binaries in a directory with the name of your choosing. In MonoGame you can rename the .mgcb file or rename the directory it resides in, but the msbuild system will always copy it to a directory named Content in the target directory.

Firstly this is a problem because it differs from XNA. Secondly this is a problem because you have no way to separate the target directory of multiple content projects in a single project. This can very easily lead to file name collisions.

http://community.monogame.net/t/changing-contentroot-directory-monogame-still-builds-into-content-folder/2527

issues.title: Support for double-precision floats
issues.body:
For games that deal with large scales, double-precision (64-bit) float support is very nice to have. 

* Many large-scale games on custom engines use `double`, such as Minecraft, Star Citizen, Elite: Dangerous, Space Engineers, Grand Theft Auto, the Unigine game engine, and likely many many more. 

* Few game engines currently support `double` for legacy reasons back when CPUs weren't able to calculate `double` quickly, however, modern FPUs and SIMDs can handle double-precision without issues. Some can even use quadruple-precision at high speeds. 

* Some large scale games, like Kerbal Space Program, use `double` for math and convert back to `float` for local positioning of objects, because it uses the Unity game engine which uses single-precision floats. This isn't efficient or ideal, is difficult to program, and ends up being buggy in the end.

One way of doing this is by creating an abstract type `real_t` instead of `float` which can be `typedef` to either `float` or `double`. This is ideal because it would allow MonoGame to compile with either `float` or `double` support with minimal effort. This is how Godot is implementing it: https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/288

It may also be worthwhile to create structs like `Vector3f` and `Vector3d` which are always `float` or `double` respectively, so that creators of games can choose a fixed type to use with their scripting.

Adds O(1) EffectParameter lookups by name
issues.body:
This adds a dictionary to the immutable EffectParameters class to achieve O(1) lookups by name.
Adds a test that depends on the parameters permanently being on the same index which shouldn't be a problem except when adding parameters.

Added this because it spares you the wrapping of all your shaders because of performance reasons if you have more that one parameter. No need for the dirty-flags any more (at least in trivial shaders where the variables are independent).
Hope that helps.

issues.title: Proposal to switch from local dependency references to NuGet packages.
issues.body:
Right now, all third party dependencies required to build MonoGame SDK are located in a [Dependencies Repository](https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame.Dependencies) and so far, this architecture has worked well.

But right now, developers are moving towards NuGet packages as the preferred mechanism to reference third party dependencies. We will have different feelings whether this is a right or wrong approach, but certainly, it's a train that cannot be stopped anymore.

More and more developers expect MonoGame to be available as NuGet packages. But in order to offer proper nuget packages, MonoGame also needs to be part of the ecosystem, which means that MonoGame should consume nuget packages when applicable.

There's already a number of third party dependencies that are available as NuGet packages, in fact, some dependencies are ONLY available as NuGet packages, SharpDX being the most notorious case, as more projects in which we depend move to NuGet, this problem will only get worse.

In the early days, a lot of work was done to provide a specific cross platform solution for MonoGame, when nothing else was available, but IDEs and NET itself have finally catched up to provide better and more powerful cross platform solutions. I understand some developers might want to work the traditional way, everything with local dependencies, etc, but not supporting NuGets is not an option anymore, and trying to keep MonoGame SDK being able to build "the old fashioned way" and "with nugets" is consuming a lot of time from the lead developers.

So my proposal is to write here some sort of roadmap for a progressive transition from local dependencies to nuget packages:

1. Identify the current problems that prevent referencing nuget packages in monogame SDK.
2. Identify which local third party dependencies can be switched to nuget packages.
3. progressively replace these dependencies, one by one.

Other issues already mentioning the Nuget package issue: #5724 #5565 #5262

issues.title: ffprobe misdetects wave files during content building
issues.body:
We get this error "Calcualted block align does not match RIFF"

![sfx-error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13956755/34644960-54d60622-f307-11e7-91b9-d44ae5d75876.JPG)

When trying to build wav files. Seems to be caused by ffprobe heuristics misdetecting it as mp4. 

[swoosh1 - Copy.zip](https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/files/1609362/swoosh1.-.Copy.zip)

We worked around it by munging the file a bit (resampling to 48k then back to 44.1k) which made the mp4 magic word no longer appear. The problem definitely wasn't in the plentiful metadata; first thing i tried was deleting that and it didn't help.

This method for identifying content is not good.

I don't really expect anyone to fix this, I'm just putting it here for findability, in case anyone else hits the same issue

issues.title: [DesktopGL] Pixel Shader compilation failed in runtime
[UWP] Wrong BackBuffer size
issues.body:
BackBufferWidth & BackBufferHeight don't always match real Window size in UWP. 

I think #5615 broke setting backbuffer sizes at startup (there is white are around rendered content). 

EDIT: Setting new preferred backbuffer sizes while in windowed mode wasn't working even before #5615 (windows size isn't changed, but backbuffer size is changed, resulting in white area around rendered content because of mismatch between window viewbounds size and backbuffer size). Also described here #5914

issues.title: Issue-6123: Guide functions were not preserving state
issues.body:
Documentation for XNA 4.0 mentions that the `BeginShowKeyboardInput` and `BeginShowMessageBox` functions take a state variable that is passed to `EndShowKeyboardInput` and `EndShowMessageBox` respectively.

MonoGame implementation violated this as it used the state variable internally, thus preventing the user from using the state variable if he wanted to do so. This PR fixes the iOS and Android implementations (ie. the ones that I was able to test on my phones).

issues.title: Check for  Invalid SpriteFonts
Enabling MSAA on RenderTargets on Windows breaks rendering after #5538
issues.body:
I know the official NuGet package does not yet support MSAA for render targets. But I found the following merged PR (https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/pull/5538). So I decided to check it out.

I've checked out the latest develop of MonoGame, build a release version for Windows and referenced it from my project (that previously used the latest NuGet package). 

When creating a render target and setting preferredMultiSampleCount to 0 everything worked as before. However when I set preferredMultiSampleCount to 2 or higher everything goes wrong. Even separate render targets that do not use any data from the render target that has enabled multi-sampling seem to break down. 

**Reproduction:**

1. Clone and build the latest version of MonoGame/develop
2. Clone https://github.com/roy-t/MiniRTS/tree/feature/MSAA_RenderTargets
3. Open MiniRTS.sln
4. Fix the reference to MonoGame.Framework to the location you have it on your machine
5. Build and run MiniRTS

**Result:**
![capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/623634/34409060-a7cf41dc-ebc7-11e7-9c23-2d86cc2c67c5.PNG)

**Expected:**
![capture2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/623634/34409078-bd3bc31a-ebc7-11e7-9270-8bf58e4e211b.PNG)

You can see how it should look by opening `RenderSystem.cs` and in the constructor change the `preferredMultiSampleCount` parameter of `this.ColorTarget` to 0.

**Tested on:**
Windows 10 1709, 64 bit
NVIDIA GeForce GTX 970 4GB

issues.title: Guid.BeginShowKeyboardInput does not persist its state object
issues.body: `BeginShowKeyboardInput` function does not persist the state object. If you pass a value in that is not null it will be overwritten by the internal `ShowKeyboardInputDelegate`. This means that the callback function cannot use its `IAsyncResult.AsyncState` object - it contains rubbish.

issues.title: GamerServices missing from nuget package
issues.body:
The GamerServices have been missing from the nuget package for several years now. Someone should mention this in the README.md and explain WHY it is no longer a part of the package and HOW TO get the functionality should you want it. Right now the only option is to not use the nuget packages at all and compile everything from github sources.

IMO the lack of information is very infortunate, the community forum was not helpful when I was digging around trying to piece information together.

issues.title: SoundEffectInstance Stop() behavior differens bewteen Windows and DesktopGL builds
issues.body:
Using monogame 3.6

If you create a SoundEffectInstance and set IsLooped to true like so:

```c#
 tireSqueal= content.Load<SoundEffect>("tire-squeal").CreateInstance();
 tireSqueal.IsLooped = true;
```

Under DesktopGL, a call to `tireSqueal.Stop(false)` will stop the sound after completion of the current loop.  In a Windows build it will never stop playing.  You have to call Stop(true), which stops it immediately, does not let the current loop finish.

pull_requests.title: Issue-6123: Guide functions were not preserving state
pull_requests.body:
Documentation for XNA 4.0 mentions that the `BeginShowKeyboardInput` and `BeginShowMessageBox` functions take a state variable that is passed to `EndShowKeyboardInput` and `EndShowMessageBox` respectively.

MonoGame implementation violated this as it used the state variable internally, thus preventing the user from using the state variable if he wanted to do so. This PR fixes the iOS and Android implementations (ie. the ones that I was able to test on my phones).

pull_requests.title: c# Replacement for Nvidia Texture Tool (fixes #6093)
pull_requests.body:
This is a fix for https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/issues/6093 , since the NVidia Texture Tool is already 10 years old, I was told that it was due to be replaced by a c# implementation.

So I've just rolled in a c# implementation of [LibSquish](https://github.com/svn2github/libsquish) the original C++ library also used by NVidia Texture Tool.

My C# library can also be found at [TextureSquish](https://github.com/vpenades/TextureSquish) , where you can also find unit tests.

The implementation code used by MonoGame is located in Graphics\DtxTexture , and it has been modified to use Microsoft.XNA.Framework.VectorX  instead of System.Numeric.Vectors, which are faster since they're SIMD accelerated, but I didn't wanted (nor I know how to) add a nuget package reference to the project.

Compression quality is set to maximum by default, this is the same behaviour as NVTT

After trying this version with our project, all the content assets compile again.

I've left the NVidia Texture Tool dependency, since I don't know if it's being used by other projects.

pull_requests.title: Binary search for curve evaluation
pull_requests.body:
In `Curve.Evaluate`, instead of looping through the keys to find those surrounding the evaluation point, I tried a binary search. It reduced the vertex buffer creation time for a large scene from a few seconds to around one second. For debug builds it went from minutes to a few seconds.

Since the underlying List container `Curve._keys._keys` (ie. `CurveKeyCollection._keys`) is private I had to make a public method `CurveKeyCollection.IndexAtPosition` in which I do the search.

The code you have implemented, to check for XNBm is to handle the WP7 xnb format. That means Windows or XBox XNA4 binaries will not work as they have XNBw and XNBx headers. I believe the Rectangle.Intersects methods would be more efficient if the by-value called the by-ref, rather than the by-ref calling the by-value.  The purpose of by-ref methods is to be faster.  By having the by-ref call the by-value, you lose all benefits of using the by-ref version.

In XNA, Color channels are expressed in the range 0.0-1.0 when represented by floats and 0-255 when using integers.  Your FromNonPremultiplied(Vector4) would truncate all channels to zero except for those channels that were at full (1.0).

We do appreciate a "new-starter" perspective. So over time we will make it easier. For example in the v2.5 release we will have project templates for certain platforms, and we will increase support for other platforms leading up to v3.0 release.

In XNA clears are affected by scissor. Why this change?

In Direct3D, the clear is not affected by the scissor rect.  In OpenGL,
clear is affected by scissor rect.  To maintain the same behaviour as XNA,
the scissor rect needs to be reset before the clear.

On 28 August 2012 06:30, kaalus notifications@github.com wrote:

> In XNA clears are affected by commit. Why this change?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/mono/MonoGame/commit/a9e207ae17182a902355e552e357db1c975937aa#commitcomment-1771938.

@slygamer 

Do you think it would be better if we restored the ScissorRect to its previous state after the Clear()?

Note that we have a patch coming that will remove all redundant GL state settings... so you don't need to worry about that issue.
- Tom

I wasn't too worried about redundant state change because the scissor rect
is already tested for that before the change is applied.

XNA 4.0 takes the path of "assume nothing: explicitly set everything you
depend on before drawing." (
http://blogs.msdn.com/b/shawnhar/archive/2010/04/02/state-objects-in-xna-game-studio-4-0.aspx
)

If some code requires a specific scissor rect, it should always set it.

I agree with what you're saying... you shouldn't assume these things and XNA is designed with that in mind.  Still MonoGame is not just following XNA theory... we're replicating its behavior.

If XNA doesn't reset the ScissorRect after the clear then we shouldn't be either.  Especially since in this case it is easy for us to make it work like XNA does.

I'll double check the XNA behavior...  if you're good with this being fixed then i'll submit it as part of my next pull.
- Tom
